channel.title: How to improve my speed
channel.description:
Track season is about to start for me, and I really love the 400 meter dash. I'm one of the top Sophomores in my county and the primary runner at the school(we have a really shitty track program atm), but that's not really good enough for me. I really want to know how to improve my 400 time, like what workouts, ect. I also have plenty of cardio due to the Cross Country season ending only 3 weeks ago.
I was thinking a good workout would be four 100m repeats, four 200m repeats, and maybe four 400m repeats. But I really have no idea...
My best time freshmen year was about 55.04 which dropped about 3 seconds from my previous best, and I'm hoping to drop another 3 seconds this year.
Has anyone here trained for the 400m before? If so what were your work outs, and any other tips you can give me.

item.dc:creator: @kronixz kronikz
item.description:
@kronixz wrote:

I do track as well, but everything TEA listed is true.

I got a trainer at my local gym, the best thing that helps me is working your core. not your legs, not your arms, but your core. Yes it is good to work other but you are already running etc so I will tell you the core stuff. There’s a thing called a “Core Ball” well it is just a regular exercise ball. There a basic exercises with this and your core is the most important part. Try to get a trainer to help you at the local gym. It’s very much improved my speed.

Hope this helped.

item.title: How to improve my speed
item.dc:creator: @asshole_rule asshole_rule
item.description:
@asshole_rule wrote:

the elve age:

• Stretching. You need to become better at stretching, I’ve heard before that the better you can stretch the more athleticism you have and the more your muscles can input and output.

Yea I try to always stretch before and after I run, but I have some serious flexibility problems.

the elve age:

• Have you started working out? Some good exercises are “calf ups” when you go up and down just raising your foot up and working your calves out. Once your calves start burning, keep going (not too long or you could hurt them). Once you’ve gotten basic calf raises start doing them over stair cases or over something that gives you more gravity on the back of your foot, continue to go up and down.

I actually do those while I’m showering, lol.

the elve age:

• If you get into a workout room, do squats. Not just any squats, but speed-squats. They are squats but you only put about half of your weight on the bar. Go up and down as fast as you can and do 3-4 sets of 12. Doing this will increase your muscles “fast-twitch” response (surely you’ve heard of fast-twitch/slow-twitch muscles).

I think I’ll try that, seems like a good idea.

the elve age:

• Start running long distance. I can’t tell you how important it is to get a good balance of both sprinting and running long distance. Long distance will make you a better runner.

I do plenty of long distance, I just finished the cross country season. Our workouts were

Monday - 10 miles
Tuesday - 8 miles
Wednesday - track workout, usually speed work
Thursday - Mile repeats, or more speed work
Friday - Easy day, because it was the day before our meets. Usually only ran like 1 or 2 miles.

We have a new sprinting coach, so I’m not to sure if he’ll send us on some distance runs, but I’ll try to find a way to get them in.

the elve age:

• Try sprinting up hill. Think about it, if you get really good at sprinting up hill, then on the flat ground you’ll kick ass.

I actually used to do that in Football conditioning, but I live in Florida, so we don’t have many hills. We do run up the stadium though, which isn’t the same, but it’s got similar concepts.

the elve age:

• Technique, have you started looking for better techniques or ways to actually improve your running form?

I don’t mean to sound conceded, but I’ve got really good form. I had a personal trainer for about 2 summers that helped me perfect my form. Also, my Mom being a state champion back in the day is really picky about my form.

Thanks for the tips.

item.title: How to improve my speed
item.dc:creator: @the_elve_age the elve age
item.description:
@the_elve_age wrote:

I’m an experienced runner and I’ve been running for 4+ years.

• Stretching. You need to become better at stretching, I’ve heard before that the better you can stretch the more athleticism you have and the more your muscles can input and output.

• Have you started working out? Some good exercises are “calf ups” when you go up and down just raising your foot up and working your calves out. Once your calves start burning, keep going (not too long or you could hurt them). Once you’ve gotten basic calf raises start doing them over stair cases or over something that gives you more gravity on the back of your foot, continue to go up and down.

• If you get into a workout room, do squats. Not just any squats, but speed-squats. They are squats but you only put about half of your weight on the bar. Go up and down as fast as you can and do 3-4 sets of 12. Doing this will increase your muscles “fast-twitch” response (surely you’ve heard of fast-twitch/slow-twitch muscles).

• Start running long distance. I can’t tell you how important it is to get a good balance of both sprinting and running long distance. Long distance will make you a better runner.

• Try sprinting up hill. Think about it, if you get really good at sprinting up hill, then on the flat ground you’ll kick ass.

• Technique, have you started looking for better techniques or ways to actually improve your running form?
